c74object.name: bach.tonnetz
c74object.description: Lattice diagram representing the (diatonic or chromatic) space of pitches, generated by two intervals or via an equation. Each point can also have a velocity, and points can be selected to form chords.

inlet.digest: Midicents or Note Names, or a 2-depth list with interleaved Velocities
Pitch-Classes, or a 2-depth list with interleaved Velocities
inlet.description: A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.

inlet.digest: Diatonic Intervals, or a 3-depth list of interlaced Diatonic Intervals and Velocities
Node Coordinates, or a 3-depth list of interlaced Node Coordinates and Velocities

outlet.digest: Selected nodes' midicents or note names
bang when changed via the interface
outlet.description: A bang is output whenever the user changes the diagram via mouse and keyboard

method.name: (keyboard)
method.description:
• Cmd+T (mac) or Ctrl+T (win): Rotate tonnetz selection of 60° clockwise
• Cmd+R (mac) or Ctrl+R (win): Rotate tonnetz selection of 60° counterclockwise
• Cmd+Shift+D (mac) or Ctrl+Shift+D (win): Dump all information (as for dump message).
• Cmd+→ (mac) or Ctrl+→ (win): Transpose tonnetz selection on horizontal coordinate, at right.
• Cmd+← (mac) or Ctrl+← (win): Transpose tonnetz selection on horizontal coordinate, at left.
• Cmd+↑ (mac) or Ctrl+↑ (win): Transpose tonnetz selection on diagonal coordinate, up.
• Cmd+↓ (mac) or Ctrl+↓ (win): Transpose tonnetz selection on diagonal coordinate, down.
• Esc: Reset offset, setting the tonnetz center at the graphical center
• Spacebar: Dump all information from the "Queries and Notifications" outlet (as for dumpselection message).

method.name: (mouse)
method.digest: Select/deselect points, or change their velocities
method.description:
• click: Select a point, and output
↪ Hold the mouse down and drag to select other points.
• Alt+click: Output clicked point data from the "Queries and Notifications" output, without selecting the point. See below to know more about the syntax.
• Cmd+click (mac) or Ctrl+click (win): Deselect a point
↪ Hold the mouse down and drag to deselect other points.
• Ctrl+click+drag (mac) or Shift+Ctrl+click+drag (win): Change the velocity of a point (dragging up or down)
• Cmd+mousewheel (mac) or Ctrl+mousewheel (win): drag up/down to increase or decrease the lattice side.
↪ Add the Shift key to slow change.
• Alt+Ctrl+click+drag (mac) or Alt+Ctrl+Shift+click+drag (win): move lattice center (change offset).
When a point is clicked upon, selected or de-selected, its content is output from the "Queries and Notifications" outlet, having as router the clicked symbol, and as syntax the complete point information syntax.
The complete point information syntax is the form in which point data is output from the query outlet. Up to a custom initial router, it has the following form: cents pitch-class WRAPPED_DIATONIC_INTERVAL_FROM_CENTER WRAPPED_COORDINATES, where WRAPPED_DIATONIC_INTERVAL_FROM_CENTER is in the llll diatonic intervals syntax, and WRAPPED_COORDINATES are the coordinates to get to the tonnetz point from the tonnetz center.
A diatonic interval is by default characterized by a couple of integer numbers (list form of diatonic intervals): the width of the interval in diatonic steps, and the width of the interval in chromatic steps. The number of diatonic steps in an octave is always 7, while the number of chromatic steps depends on the modulo; by default, in the semitonal system, it is 12. In such system, for instance, an ascending major third will be represented by 2 4, since we need 2 diatonic steps and 4 chromatic steps to get from the bottom to the top note. As further examples, the interval between C5 and D#5 is 1 3, and the interval between E#4 and Fb5 is 8 11.
You can usually specify the diatonic interval also by directly inputting the width of the interval in midicents. However this is always ambiguous, and bach will chose one of the infinite diatonic ways to interpret such interval - ideally, the "simplest" one: 700 is a major fifth, 300 is a minor third (and not an augmented second), and so on.
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.
The coordinate of a point of the tonnetz is the position of such point in the oblique grid created by the horizontal axis, passing for the tonnetz center, and the diagonal axis, at 60° counterclockwise from the horizontal one, again passing for the tonnetz center. Coordinates above the center and at right have positive values, below and at left have negative ones. Each point can be uniquely determined by the amount of steps one must take rightwards from the center (coordinate 1) and diagonlly upwards at 60° (coordinate 2) in order to get to the point.

method.name: int
method.description: In the sixth inlet, an int sets the modulo (number of points in the clock). In first and second inlet, an int is converted into an llll.

method.name: llll
method.digest: Set points and/or velocities (depending on inlet)
method.description:
The first four (hot) inlets accepts llll determining which should be the selected points: user should use either one of these inlets to insert data.
The fifth inlet accepts a plain llll setting the velocities correspond to the list given in either one of the hot inlets.
The first inlet sets the selected points starting from their midicents values or from the note names. A plain llll with midicents or note names (or both) is thus expected.
The second inlet sets the selected points starting from their pitch-class. A plain list of pitch-classes is thus expected.
The third inlet sets the selected points starting from their diatonic interval with respect to the tonnetz center (see center attribute). An llll of depth 2, each sublist containing a diatonic interval, is thus expected (see below to know more about diatonic intervals syntax: only the list syntax can be used, not the midicent one - use the first inlet if you need to set midicents).
The fourth inlet sets the selected points starting from their coordinates inside the tonnetz (see below).
If the autoclear attribute is active (default), the current selection is cleared before performing the new one.
If the echo attribute is active, the newly selected or de-selected point information is also output from the "Queries and Notification" outlet (seventh outlet), in the complete point information syntax, having the echo symbol as router.

method.name: replace
rotate
method.description: Rotate all the selected points in the lattice of a certain angle multiple of 60°. The expected argument is such multiplier (number of steps): with rotate 1 the tonnetz is rotated counterclockwise by 60°, with rotate 2 it is rotated clockwise by 120°, and so on. Negative number rotate counterclockwise.

method.name: translate
method.description: Translate all the selected points in the lattice of a certain vector, specified in the lattice coordinates. The expected arguments are thus the two integer coordinates for the translation.

attribute.name: autoclear
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically clear the content once new data arrives in the four hot inlets.

attribute.name: bgcolor
attribute.description: Diagram external background color

attribute.name: bordercolor
attribute.description: Color of the diagram border

attribute.name: center
attribute.description: Sets the diatonic center as a diatonic interval with respect to the middle C(i.e. as a couple of long numbers: the number of diatonic steps and the number of chromatic steps). E.g. D# above middle C is 1 3 since there's 1 diatonic step from C to D and 3 chromatic steps from C to D#. You can also set the center directly as midicents, in which case it is automatically converted into a note, and thus by default to a diatonic interval (e.g. 6700 meaning G above middle C, 6300 meaning Eb above middle C, and not D# – use the list syntax to express specific enharmonicities).

attribute.name: label
match
middlecoctave
attribute.description: Sets the octave number of the middle C. By default this is 4 (meaning that C4 = Do4 is the middle C); values of 3 and 5 are also encountered.

modulo
attribute.description:
Modulo of the diagram.
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.

attribute.name: notenamesstyle
attribute.description: In the bach environment you can choose to represent note names in two different ways: either with the latin symbols (Do, Re, Mi, Fa, Sol, La, Si) or with the anglo-saxon letters (C, D, E, F, G, A, B).

attribute.name: offset
attribute.description: Sets the center offset in lattice coordinates.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: outputnotenames
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to output note names from first inlet, instead of midicents, when a dump message is sent. (or a dump is required from keyboard combinations).

attribute.name: pointbordercolor
attribute.description: Color of each point's outline

attribute.name: pointinnercolor
attribute.description: Color of the inner part of each point.

attribute.name: pointlinewidth
attribute.description: Width of the line of each point's tonnetz, in pixels

attribute.name: pointradius
attribute.description: Radius of each tonnetz point in pixels

attribute.name: purelydiatonic
attribute.description: s If set, forces the tonnetz generators to be purely diatonic: the chromatic steps of the generators are ignored, and instead a default interval sequence (scale) is used (see scaleintervals and scalefreqratios).

attribute.name: scalefreqratios
attribute.description: s If purelydiatonic is active, this specifies the frequency intervals related to the current scale steps.

entry.name: Inlet 2 (llll)
entry.description: Pitch-Classes, or a 2-depth list with interleaved Velocities. A pitch-class set is a plain collection of pitch-classes. A pitch class is nothing but the representative of a set of pitches. Traditionally, it corresponds to the concept of "note", once we abstract it from its octave. For instance, the semitonal framework (when the modulo is 12), all the C belong to the same pitch-class which will be named 0 = {..., C-1, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, ...}. The pitch-class 1 will be the one containing all C#'s (or Db's); pitch-class 2 will contain all D's, and so on. One will use to name pitch class numbers from 0 to the modulo - 1: indeed, with modulo = 12, pitch-class 12 will coincide with pitch-class 0 (it'll be the C one octave higher). One can thus think at pitch-classes as equally spaced points on a clock, and transposing means rotating them on the clock. A pitch class set is thus represented just by a plain list of pitch classes, such 0 4 7, representing the C major chord. Notice that this coincides with any other representation such as 12 4 19 or 0 -8 -5, but the canonical form, where numbers are from 0 to the modulo-1 is always preferred. Also for pitch-class sets the order of elements is immaterial, and thus 0 4 7 or 4 0 7 or 7 4 0 will all represent the same set. On the other hand a pitch-class (as an abstract concept) can be used to represent things other than pitches, as for instance temporal position in a rhythmic pattern (loop) having a certain number (the modulo) of equally spaced elements.
